text.p: Manpower Inc chief executive Mitchell Fromstein said he was comfortable with Wall Street analysts' 1996 earnings estimates of about $1.80 per share.
He said the company advised analysts to lower their estimates by $0.05 to roughly that level in a conference call on Monday.
"We suggested they bring it down to $1.80 for 1996," Fromstein told Reuters in an interview.
The reason for the earnings estimate cut was weakness in the French economy. Manpower operations in France generate about a third of the staffing services company's revenues.

The French economy is weak, Fromstein said. "It looked like it was going to improve in June, July and August, our big months there, and the improvement came. But it just didn't come as strongly as we anticipated," he said.

"We're still doing very well there. We're gaining market share, but the market itself is pretty flat," he said. "Because France is a large part of our revenue stream and our profit stream, we thought that the estimates were too high."
The consensus of analysts' 1996 earnings estimates prior to the conference call had been $1.85 per share, he said.
Operations elsewhere in the Manpower system around the world are doing well, especially in Japan and the United States, he said.
Shares in the Milwaukee-based firm were off 3-1/4 to 31.
